title: Baskerville/Caslon???
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007175800im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/capital_5672.jpg)

This is baffling me, it seems to have the C from Baskerville and the T from Caslon. can some one tell me if there is another face out there that shares these two forms??

Thank You.

 [‹ Directory Listing from 1881](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007175800/http:/www.typophile.com/node/30195 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) "Imagine your possibilities" delicate italic serif - Linotype Didot {Lari} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007175800/http:/www.typophile.com/node/30191 "Go to next forum topic")
author: metafourik

comments.content:
There was a Caslon Bold that was made by Electronic Font Foundry that used the C you are talking about - which appears to be Horley OS

See: [http://eff.co.uk/W/P/EveRR.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20081007175800/http:/eff.co.uk/W/P/EveRR.htm "http://eff.co.uk/W/P/EveRR.htm")
The A is not Caslon, as it always has a spur to the left at the top. The C with two spurs is found on the larger sizes of the original Caslon. The T of Horley Old Style is different.
